tables.description: Track YARA matches for files or PIDs.
examples: select * from yara where path LIKE '/etc/%'

tables.name: yara

tables.name: appcompat_shims

columns.description: Name of the key to search for
columns.name: key

columns.description: Name of the registry value entry
columns.name: name

columns.description: Type of the registry value, or 'subkey' if item is a subkey
columns.name: type

columns.description: timestamp of the most recent registry write
columns.name: mtime

tables.description: All of the Windows registry hives.
examples: select path, key, name from registry where key = 'HKEY_USERS'; -- get user SIDS. Note: path is key+name
select path from registry where key like 'HKEY_USERS\.Default\%'; -- a SQL wildcard match; will not recurse subkeys
select path from registry where key like 'HKEY_USERS\.Default\Software\%%'; -- recursing query (compare with 1 %)
select path from registry where key like 'HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Micr%ft\%' and type = 'subkey' LIMIT 10; -- midfix wildcard match

select name, type, data from registry where path like 'HKEY_USERS\%\Control Panel\International\User Profile\Languages'; -- get users' current UI language. Note: osquery cannot reference HKEY_CURRENT_USER
select name, type, data from registry where path like 'HKEY_USERS\%\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Wallpapers\%';  -- list all of the desktop wallpapers
select name, type, data from registry where key like 'HKEY_USERS\%\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Wallpapers'; -- same, but filtering by key instead of path
tables.name: registry

columns.description: Standard string template that specifies the process to be started. This property can be NULL, and the ExecutablePath property is used as the command line.

tables.description: WMI CommandLineEventConsumer, which can be used for persistance on Windows. See https://www.blackhat.com/docs/us-15/materials/us-15-Graeber-Abusing-Windows-Management-Instrumentation-WMI-To-Build-A-Persistent%20Asynchronous-And-Fileless-Backdoor-wp.pdf for more details.
examples: select filter,consumer,query,command_line_template,wcec.name from wmi_cli_event_consumers wcec left outer join wmi_filter_consumer_binding wcb on consumer = wcec.relative_path left outer join wmi_event_filters wef on wef.relative_path = wcb.filter;
tables.name: wmi_cli_event_consumers

columns.description: Unique identifier of an event filter.
columns.name: name

columns.description: Windows Management Instrumentation Query Language (WQL) event query that specifies the set of events for consumer notification, and the specific conditions for notification.
columns.name: query

columns.description: Query language that the query is written in.
columns.name: query_language

columns.description: Relative path to the class or instance.
columns.name: relative_path

tables.description: Lists WMI event filters.
tables.name: wmi_event_filters

columns.description: Reference to an instance of __EventConsumer that represents the object path to a logical consumer, the recipient of an event.
columns.name: consumer

columns.description: Reference to an instance of __EventFilter that represents the object path to an event filter which is a query that specifies the type of event to be received.
columns.name: filter

columns.description: Relative path to the class or instance.
columns.name: relative_path

tables.description: Lists the relationship between event consumers and filters.
tables.name: wmi_filter_consumer_binding

columns.description: Unique identifier for the event consumer.
columns.name: name

columns.description: Name of the scripting engine to use, for example, 'VBScript'. This property cannot be NULL.
columns.name: scripting_engine

columns.description: Name of the file from which the script text is read, intended as an alternative to specifying the text of the script in the ScriptText property.
columns.name: script_file_name

columns.description: Text of the script that is expressed in a language known to the scripting engine. This property must be NULL if the ScriptFileName property is not NULL.
columns.name: script_text

columns.description: Relative path to the class or instance.
columns.name: relative_path

tables.description: WMI ActiveScriptEventConsumer, which can be used for persistance on Windows. See https://www.blackhat.com/docs/us-15/materials/us-15-Graeber-Abusing-Windows-Management-Instrumentation-WMI-To-Build-A-Persistent%20Asynchronous-And-Fileless-Backdoor-wp.pdf for more details.
examples: select filter,consumer,query,scripting_engine,script_file_name,script_text,wsec.name from wmi_script_event_consumers wsec left outer join wmi_filter_consumer_binding wcb on consumer = wsec.relative_path left outer join wmi_event_filters wef on wef.relative_path = wcb.filter;
tables.name: wmi_script_event_consumers

columns.description: Organization name followed by a period and an extension that indicates the type of organization, such as 'microsoft.com'.
columns.name: dns_domain

columns.description: Array of DNS domain suffixes to be appended to the end of host names during name resolution.
columns.name: dns_domain_suffix_search_order

columns.description: Host name used to identify the local computer for authentication by some utilities.
columns.name: dns_host_name

columns.description: Array of server IP addresses to be used in querying for DNS servers.
columns.name: dns_server_search_order

tables.description: Detailed information and stats of network interfaces.
examples: select interface, mac, type, idrops as input_drops from interface_details;
select interface, mac, type, flags, (1<<8) as promisc_flag from interface_details where (flags & promisc_flag) > 0;
select interface, mac, type, flags, (1<<3) as loopback_flag from interface_details where (flags & loopback_flag) > 0;
tables.name: interface_details

tables.description: Basic active kernel information.
tables.name: kernel_info

tables.description: Processes with listening (bound) network sockets/ports.
tables.name: listening_ports

tables.description: Users with an active shell on the system.
tables.name: logged_in_users

columns.description: Pretty, suitable for presentation, OS version
columns.name: version

tables.description: A single row containing the operating system name and version.
tables.name: os_version

tables.description: Information about EFI/UEFI/ROM and platform/boot.
tables.name: platform_info

columns.description: Path to mapped file or mapped type
columns.name: path

columns.description: 1 If path is a pseudo path, else 0
columns.name: pseudo

tables.description: Process memory mapped files and pseudo device/regions.
tables.name: process_memory_map

columns.description: For UNIX sockets (family=AF_UNIX), the domain path
columns.name: path

tables.description: Processes which have open network sockets on the system.
tables.name: process_open_sockets

columns.description: The process path or shorthand argv[0]
columns.name: name

columns.description: The process path exists yes=1, no=0, unknown=-1
columns.name: on_disk

columns.description: Bytes of unpagable memory used by process
columns.name: wired_size

columns.description: Bytes of private memory used by process
columns.name: resident_size

columns.description: CPU time spent in user space
columns.name: user_time

columns.description: CPU time spent in kernel space
columns.name: system_time

columns.description: Process start in seconds since boot (non-sleeping)
columns.name: start_time

columns.description: Number of threads used by process
columns.name: threads

tables.description: All running processes on the host system.
tables.name: processes

columns.description: Maximum Transmission Unit for the route
columns.name: mtu

columns.description: Cost of route. Lowest is preferred
columns.name: metric

tables.description: The active route table for the host system.
tables.name: routes

columns.description: Directory or plist containing startup item
columns.name: source

columns.description: Startup status; either enabled or disabled
columns.name: status

columns.description: The user associated with the startup item
columns.name: username

tables.description: Applications and binaries set as user/login startup items.
tables.name: startup_items

columns.description: Unique ID provided by the system
columns.name: uuid

columns.description: CPU brand string, contains vendor and model
columns.name: cpu_brand

columns.description: Max number of CPU physical cores
columns.name: cpu_physical_cores

columns.description: Max number of CPU logical cores
columns.name: cpu_logical_cores

tables.description: System information for identification.
tables.name: system_info

tables.description: Track time passed since last boot.
tables.name: uptime

columns.description: Default group ID as int64 signed (Apple)
columns.name: gid_signed

tables.description: Local system users.
examples: select count(*) from users u, user_groups ug where u.uid = ug.uid
tables.name: users

columns.description: 1 if the path is a symlink, otherwise 0
columns.name: symlink

tables.description: Interactive filesystem attributes and metadata.
examples: select * from file where path LIKE '/etc/%'
tables.name: file

columns.description: Number of subscriptions the publisher received or subscriber used
columns.name: subscriptions

columns.description: Number of events emitted or received since osquery started
columns.name: events

columns.description: Publisher only: number of runloop restarts
columns.name: refreshes

columns.description: 1 if the publisher or subscriber is active else 0
columns.name: active

tables.description: Information about the event publishers and subscribers.
tables.name: osquery_events

columns.description: The transient ID assigned for communication
columns.name: uuid

columns.description: osquery SDK version used to build the extension
columns.name: sdk_version

columns.description: Path of the extenion's domain socket or library path
columns.name: path

columns.description: SDK extension type: extension or module
columns.name: type

tables.description: List of active osquery extensions.
tables.name: osquery_extensions

tables.description: Configurable flags that modify osquery's behavior.
tables.name: osquery_flags

columns.description: Unique ID provided by the system
columns.name: uuid

columns.description: Unique, long-lived ID per instance of osquery
columns.name: instance_id

columns.description: Hash of the working configuration state
columns.name: config_hash

columns.description: 1 if the config was loaded and considered valid, else 0
columns.name: config_valid

columns.description: osquery toolkit platform distribution name (os version)
columns.name: build_distro

columns.description: UNIX time in seconds when the process started
columns.name: start_time

columns.description: Process (or thread/handle) ID of optional watcher process
columns.name: watcher

tables.description: Top level information about the running version of osquery.
tables.name: osquery_info

columns.description: The given name for this query pack
columns.name: name

columns.description: Platforms this query is supported on
columns.name: platform

columns.description: Minimum osquery version that this query will run on
columns.name: version

columns.description: Shard restriction limit, 1-100, 0 meaning no restriction
columns.name: shard

columns.description: The number of times that the discovery query used cached values since the last time the config was reloaded
columns.name: discovery_cache_hits

columns.description: The number of times that the discovery queries have been executed since the last time the config was reloaded
columns.name: discovery_executions

columns.description: Whether this pack is active (the version, platform and discovery queries match) yes=1, no=0.
columns.name: active

tables.description: Information about the current query packs that are loaded in osquery.
tables.name: osquery_packs

columns.description: 1 If the plugin is internal else 0
columns.name: internal

columns.description: 1 If this plugin is active else 0
columns.name: active

tables.description: List the osquery registry plugins.
tables.name: osquery_registry

columns.description: The given name for this query
columns.name: name

columns.description: The interval in seconds to run this query, not an exact interval
columns.name: interval

columns.description: Number of times the query was executed
columns.name: executions

columns.description: UNIX time stamp in seconds of the last completed execution
columns.name: last_executed

columns.description: Total number of bytes generated by the query
columns.name: output_size

columns.description: Average private memory left after executing
columns.name: average_memory

tables.description: Information about the current queries that are scheduled in osquery.
tables.name: osquery_schedule

columns.description: Current local UNIX time in the system
columns.name: local_time

columns.description: Current local timezone in the system
columns.name: local_timezone

columns.description: Current UNIX time in the system, converted to UTC if --utc enabled
columns.name: unix_time

columns.description: Current timestamp (log format) in the system
columns.name: timestamp

columns.description: Current date and time (ISO format) in the system
columns.name: datetime

columns.description: Current time (ISO format) in the system
columns.name: iso_8601

tables.description: Track current date and time in the system.
tables.name: time
